data.title: Intellisense breaks if not suppying null for optional parameters
Is it possible to link typescript interfaces to JSON files?
data.body: I know it's possible to do this [with json schemas](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/languages/json#_json-schemas-settings) but is it possible to do this with a typescript interface?

data.title: /usr/bin/code not linked when doing rpm upgrade
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Fedora
## Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install an old version (for example 1.1) of code
2. run `dnf install https://az764295.vo.msecnd.net/stable/fe7f407b95b7f78405846188259504b34ef72761/vscode-x86_64.rpm`
3. `/usr/bin/code` is not created.
## Details

The problem is that /usr/bin/code is not a part of the rpm.
`/usr/bin/code` is created in postinstall script as:

```
# Symlink bin command to /usr/bin
sudo rm -f /usr/bin/code
sudo ln -s /usr/share/code/bin/code /usr/bin/code
```

In the `postuninstall` script, `/usr/bin/code` is removed.

In first installation of `code`, only `postinstall` script is executed. So it works well.
However, when doing an upgrade, `postinstall` and `postuninstall` script are both executed. So `/usr/bin/code` is removed.
## Possible solutions
- make `/usr/bin/code` as part of the rpm package. (my recommendation)

Or
- check the argument of `postinstall`. Only remove `/usr/bin/code` when the argument is 1.
  ( see explanations on `Install/Erase-time Scripts` part of http://www.rpm.org/max-rpm/s1-rpm-inside-scripts.html )

data.title: Switching branches results in spurious TypeScript errors

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a few files in a git TypeScript project
2. Modify two files (`a.ts` and `b.ts`) that depend on one another and commit them.
3. Switch to a different branch and reload all the files. Make sure only `a.ts` is visible.
4. Switch back to the first branch. `a.ts` reports errors.

Opening `b.ts`, either in a tab or split, will make the errors in `a.ts` go away. Even if you don't save. Running `tsc` from the command line never reports any errors. It seems like vscode isn't reloading files that aren't being actively edited when I switch branches.

This doesn't _always_ happen, just often enough to be noticeable.

data.title: List content in markdown should not be styled
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16129556/fd739e2a-33b9-11e6-85c4-ddd6d9b51b90.png)

The text after the `*` should be white and links should be styled as links.

Note that removing the markup scope from all elements fixes the issue, it does remove heading coloring though which is also important:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16129691/a86c6c62-33ba-11e6-81d9-82d9590829dd.png)

data.title: Request: VS Code Help>About text should be selectable or auto-copy to clipboard useful info for filing an issue.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: 10586.318

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Want to file a bug.
2. Click on the "Report Issues" link.
3. Realize I need to open `winver` to get the OS version, and VS Code Help>About to get the VS Code version -- and this dialog does not have selectable text so I need to transcribe the info, and I end up only transcribing the Version 1.2.1 because everything else is too difficult.

Request: VS Code Help>About text should be selectable or auto-copy to clipboard useful info for filing an issue.

Bonus: Also detect the OS version number and build string so that info can be copied into a bug as well.

This would make opening issues with the most useful data way easier -- win-win for VS Code devs and for users filing bugs!

data.title: Drag and drop from Explorer onto VS Code sometimes doesn't work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: 10586.318

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code (only instance with --disable-extensions)
2. Drag a file in to VS Code to open
3. Notice that file didn't open and was not added to the file list
4. Try to open the file again (usually works this time)

Does not consistently repro AFAICT. Might have something to do with window focus of explorer window and VS Code?

Sometimes happens while VS Code has been open for a while and has many instances and many files, but I have also seen it happen for the very first file I tried to open in a fresh instance of VS Code (as above) with no other instances or files open.

data.title: Drag and drop from Explorer onto VS Code multiple times resulted in "associated text model is undefined" error.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: 10586.318

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code (only instance with `--disable-extensions`)
2. Drag a file in to VS Code to open
3. Close file
4. Remove from file list (multiple times)
5. Repeat 2-4 several times.
6. Encounter the following error:
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16129352/57075c7a-33b9-11e6-9d3e-b54c0eabae4b.png)
7. From then on, unable to open that file despite it being a valid file.

Restarting VS Code fixes the problem.

(I have had difficulty reproing this issue myself -- I'm not sure how to better reproduce the issue.)

Discovered while trying to repro https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7787

``` json
  "explorer.openEditors.visible": 0,
  "workbench.quickOpenPreviews": false
}
```

data.title: Open Editors view is not assigning truly unique ids?
data.body:
I am playing around with the new markdown preview and it seems that the IDs we use in the opened editors view are not truly unique. E.g. they just seem to rely on the name of the input which can be identical for two different inputs:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/16124778/be7165fe-33f0-11e6-947c-cd92db56fe57.png)

data.title: HTMLPart to survive restarts?
data.body:
I am not sure if there is a technical reason for not implementing a `IEditorInputFactory` so that previews (e.g. markdown) survive a restart or refresh. Is it that we can only have the input when the extension is ready?

An example factory for file inputs is here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/files.contribution.ts#L127

Today when you close and restart the markdown preview is closed. With our old markdown preview we were able to persist and restore it given the factory.

//cc @jrieken @kieferrm

data.title: Display viewlet temporarily on mouseover

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It would be cool if viewlets displayed on a delayed mouseover (on top or in place of the currently opened viewlet), and would hide on a mouseout (showing the primary open viewlet again). When you click on the viewlet icon it would still then make that the primary opened viewlet like it does now.

So like is said in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/7704 (future support for custom viewlets), it could be nice to have this, because I don't always want to have a viewlet open, I just want to take a "peek" for a second.

For example say there is a `Navigator` viewlet that displayed all the classes/methods/properties/etc. in the currently opened file. So, what I would do mouse over the `Navigator` icon and it would open, then say I click on `Method`, it would then navigate to the correct line where that `Method` is defined. Once I moused off of the viewlet it would then close and my `Files` viewlet would come back (or whatever one I had opened prior to the mouseover).

**Edit**

This would also be helpful when the viewlets are in a collapsed state (activated by pressing <kbd>Ctrl+B</kbd>).

data.title: 'End' key not working on trimmed long lines

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file with a very long line - over the limit of 10000
2. Position the cursor at the start of the line in question
3. Press 'End' keyboard key

Result - the 'End' key does nothing, while it rather has to go to the end of the trimmed/loaded part of the line.

All-in-all, I must say the approach to treating long lines is one of the worst shortcomming of VS Code (along with not being able to load big files at all). This approach makes the editor totally unusable for touching minified scripts and css for example, so I'd rather say you have to think of improving the performance and removing this serious limitation.

data.title: Project Management
data.body: An idea for an improvement is creating a builtin Project manager. (Could be git projects) So that you don't need to open folders in the editor.

data.title: Default Keyboard Shortcuts file has dup key conflict
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: win10

Steps to Reproduce:

The dup keys are....
{ "key": "ctrl+shift+t",          "command": "workbench.action.reopenClosedEditor" },
{ "key": "ctrl+shift+t",          "command": "launcher.terminal" },

Since launcher.terminal occurs last, the ctrl-shift-t shortcut opens the exernal terminal.
This shortcut should reopen the last closed editor window.

Proposed Solution....
remap the launcher.terminal key to default to another, nonconflicting shortcut sequence

data.title: Deleting unsaved page doesn't close the editing window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.3 Rosa

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Modify a file inside Visual Studio Code (don't save it)
2. Delete the file

As the title says. If you modify a file and then immediately delete it from the side bar (without saving it first), then the editing window is still there with the tag thing showing that it's been modified and unsaved, when it no longer exists.
